body:
Using `mtime` instead of `atime` was an explicit decision, because `atime`:

1. is more likely to be affected by other programs running on your system
2. is unreliable if you use the `relatime` mount option (once the `atime` moves past the `mtime`, it won't be updated again (*), which makes it impossible to accurately track the *last* time the file was accessed)

(*) okay, it will be updated at least once per day, but the disk cache can churn through a lot of files in the course of a day.

What if we made it so that files in the disk cache are always created with permissions `0666` (readable *and* writable by group/other) so that anyone can set the `mtime` on them? The permissions could be further locked down by setting a `umask(2)` for the Bazel process. (See https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/23405 which is essentially the same issue, but for directories instead of files.)

> What if we made it so that files in the disk cache are always created with permissions 0666 (readable and writable by group/other) so that anyone can set the mtime on them?

Now I am puzzled. I've patched Bazel to according to #23405. The cache artifact has write permissions for the group, as well as the containing directory. But I can't reproduce the behaviour using plain `touch` ‚Äì despite the fact the file as well as the directory is owned by another user and "only" a common group has write permissions:
```
disk-cache/ac/07$ ls -la 
total 12
drwxrwsr-x  2 ddad-builder shared-data 4096 Sep  4 20:25 .
drwxrwsr-x 20 user         shared-data 4096 Sep  4 18:27 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 ddad-builder shared-data  365 Sep  4 20:25 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926

disk-cache/ac/07$ id
uid=1002(user) gid=1002(user) groups=1002(user),27(sudo),108(kvm),120(libvirt),998(shared-data)

disk-cache/ac/07$ stat 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926 
  File: 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926
  Size: 365             Blocks: 8          IO Block: 4096   regular file
Device: 10306h/66310d   Inode: 209532447   Links: 1
Access: (0664/-rw-rw-r--)  Uid: ( 1016/ddad-builder)   Gid: (  998/shared-data)
Access: 2024-09-04 20:25:51.653153447 +0200
Modify: 2024-09-04 20:25:51.653153447 +0200
Change: 2024-09-04 20:25:51.653153447 +0200
 Birth: -

disk-cache/ac/07$ touch 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926

disk-cache/ac/07$ stat 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926
  File: 072b3bf19bfea2465398537ec525ed24e1392c45706214cab0a7d30fbf58e926
  Size: 365             Blocks: 8          IO Block: 4096   regular file
Device: 10306h/66310d   Inode: 209532447   Links: 1
Access: (0664/-rw-rw-r--)  Uid: ( 1016/ddad-builder)   Gid: (  998/shared-data)
Access: 2024-09-04 20:27:36.158298145 +0200
Modify: 2024-09-04 20:27:36.158298145 +0200
Change: 2024-09-04 20:27:36.158298145 +0200
 Birth: -
```

What is different when executed by Bazel?

I think the manpage for `utimensat(2)` provides the (surprising!) answer:

```
EPERM  The  caller  attempted to change one or both timestamps to a value other than the current time, or to change one of the timestamps to the current time while leaving the other timestamp un‚Äê
              changed, (i.e., times is not NULL, neither tv_nsec field is UTIME_NOW, and neither tv_nsec field is UTIME_OMIT) and either:

              ‚Ä¢  the caller's effective user ID does not match the owner of file, and the caller is not privileged (Linux: does not have the CAP_FOWNER capability); or,

              ‚Ä¢  the file is marked append-only or immutable (see chattr(1)).
```

Bazel first gets the current system time and uses it as the argument to `utimensat`, while `touch` uses a `NULL` argument (i.e., "set to current time") but only the file owner can use a non-NULL argument.

It's probably fine to fix Bazel to use a `NULL` argument, but it might have subtle implications for the garbage collection feature that I'm working on, so I'm stopping short of saying "I'll fix it" until I've had some time to ponder.
Thanks that you had a timely look. üíõ

issue.title: [7.4.0] Changing `mtime` to support cache trimming collides with a shared cache

body:
A fix for this issue has been included in [Bazel 7.4.0 RC1](https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases/tag/7.4.0rc1). Please test out the release candidate and report any issues as soon as possible.
If you're using Bazelisk, you can point to the latest RC by setting `USE_BAZEL_VERSION=7.4.0rc1`. Thanks!

> Please test out the release candidate and report any issues as soon as possible.

@iancha1992, I am very sorry, apparently I have not done yet.
The project switched to 7.5.0 a few days ago and the same issues is still present with this build:

